raw_text:
Guantanamo four free in weeks
 
 All four Britons held by the US in Guantanamo Bay will be returned to the UK within weeks, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw told the Commons on Tuesday.
 
 Moazzam Begg, from Birmingham, and Martin Mubanga, Richard Belmar and Feroz Abbasi, from London, have been held by the US for almost three years. They were detained in the Cuban camp as part of the US-led "war on terror". Mr Straw said the US had agreed to release the four after "intensive and complex discussions" over security. He said the government had been negotiating the return of the detainees since 2003. All four families have been informed of their return and have been involved in regular discussions with the government, Mr Straw said.
 
 But he added: "Once they are back in the UK, the police will consider whether to arrest them under the Terrorism Act 2000 for questioning in connection with possible terrorist activity." The shadow foreign secretary, Michael Ancram, welcomed the return of the four detainees. But he said there were still "serious questions" both over the possible threat the four pose to the UK, and the treatment they received while detained. Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman Sir Menzies Campbell said the four had been rescued from a "legal no-man's land". "Their civil rights were systematically and deliberately abused and they were denied due process."
 
 Azmat Begg, father of Moazzam, thanked his lawyers and the British people for the support he had received while campaigning for his son's release. He added: "If they have done something wrong, of course they should be punished, but if they haven't, they shouldn't have been there." Lawyer Louise Christian, who represents Mr Abbasi and Mr Mubanga, said the government should have acted sooner. She said: "They should at the outset have said quite clearly to the American government that they were behaving in breach of international law and that the British government wanted no part of it and wanted Guantanamo Bay shut down. "They didn't do that. They colluded with it." Moazzam Begg's Labour MP Roger Godsiff welcomed his release, but said questions remained unanswered, particularly about charges. Asked about possible damages Mr Begg and the other detainees could bring against the US, Mr Godsiff said: "People get released from prison when it's found that their prosecution was unsustainable and they are quite rightly awarded sizeable sums of money. "I don't see any difference in this case." Human rights campaigners have been outraged at the treatment of the detainees in Cuba. Amnesty International has called Camp Delta a "major human-rights scandal" and an "icon of lawlessness". Both Amnesty and the lobby group Guantanamo Human Rights Commission described the release as "long overdue". Civil rights group Liberty said it was "delighted" but called on the government to release men indefinitely detained in the UK without charge or trial.
 
 Director Shami Chakrabarti called on the government to "practise what it preaches" and either free or charge 12 detainees at Belmarsh and Woodhill prisons. Law Lords ruled last month that the 12 were being held in contravention of human rights laws but they are still behind bars. The US has also announced that 48-year-old Australian Mamdouh Habib, previously accused of terrorist offences, will be released without charge from Camp Delta. Five British detainees released from Guantanamo in March last year were questioned by UK police before being released without charge.
llama3.2:1b: Four Britons held by the US in Guantanamo Bay are to be returned to the UK within weeks.
The four have been detained since 2003 and will face questioning about possible terrorist activity once they return.
Their families have been involved in negotiations with the government, but some have raised concerns over their treatment while in detention.

Upon return, the detainees may face arrest under the Terrorism Act 2000 for questioning about possible terrorist activity.
Human rights groups have welcomed the release but expressed concerns over treatment and detention conditions.

The government negotiated their release after complex discussions with the US, informed the families of their return and engaged in regular discussions.
Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram welcomed their return while Sir Menzies Campbell criticized the treatment they received.
Lawyers criticize the delayed response and say the UK should have asserted its own legal stance against Guantanamo Bay earlier.
Human rights groups celebrate the release but call for accountability with regard to detainees' continued detention in the UK.
Director Shami Chakrabarti urged government action in releasing 12 others held at Belmarsh and Woodhill prisons in accordance with human rights laws.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The four British men held by the US in Guantanamo Bay are set to be returned to the UK within weeks.
Moazzam Begg, Richard Belmar and Feroz Abbasi were detained as part of a "war on terror" operation for almost three years while Martin Mubanga was detained in Cuba.
All four families have been informed about their return and are involved in regular discussions with the government.
There is still debate over whether the four posed a threat to the UK.
The British government has promised to release them, but questions remain about the treatment they received during their detention.
A shadow foreign secretary welcomed their return but said there were still "serious questions" about possible threats and treatment of the four.
Human rights activists have called for the US to be held indefinitely without charge or trial.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Four Britons held at Guantanamo Bay for three years have been freed after intensive negotiations with the US over security concerns.
The release comes amid debate about the treatment of detainees and potential threats posed by the individuals, as well as criticism of their previous treatment in Cuba.
The government plans to question the four under the Terrorism Act 2000 once they return to the UK.
qwen2.5:3b: All four Britons held at Guantanamo Bay for almost three years will be returned to the UK within weeks, following "intensive and complex discussions" over security.
Moazzam Begg, Richard Belmar, Feroz Abbasi, and Martin Mubanga were detained as part of the "war on terror."
They have been informed of their return and are eligible for questioning under the Terrorism Act 2000 if deemed a threat.
The shadow foreign secretary welcomed their release but raised concerns about their possible threats to UK security and treatment during detention.
Legal representatives argue that the government should have acted earlier, given international law violations.
Liberal Democrat leader Sir Menzies Campbell called for ending Guantanamo Bay's presence in the UK.
Human rights groups praised the return of detainees but also demanded immediate action on indefinitely detained Britons at Belmarsh and Woodhill prisons.

Civil rights group Liberty said the release of men indefinitely detained in the UK without charge or trial was "delightful", but cautioned about the British government's responsibility to "praticulate what it preaches" and either free or charge them.

Azmat Begg thanked his lawyers and the British people for the support he had received while campaigning for his son's release.
However, questions remain unanswered, particularly about charges.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The four Britons—Moazzam Begg, Martin Mubanga, Richard Belmar, and Feroz Abbasi—held at Guantanamo Bay for nearly three years due to the US-led "war on terror," will be returned to the UK within weeks.
Foreign Secretary Jack Straw announced this after extensive negotiations with the US regarding security concerns.
The families have been informed and consulted during these talks since 2003.
Upon their return, British police will consider arresting them under the Terrorism Act 2000 for questioning related to potential terrorist activities.

The announcement was met with mixed reactions: shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram expressed cautious optimism while raising concerns about their potential threat and treatment during detention; Sir Menzies Campbell from the Liberal Democrats emphasized the abuse of their civil rights and denial of due process.
Azmat Begg, father of Moazzam, expressed gratitude for support received in his son's release campaign, urging punishment if wrongdoing is proven.
Lawyer Louise Christian criticized the government for not immediately condemning Guantanamo Bay as a breach of international law and demanding its closure.
Moazzam Begg's Labour MP Roger Godsiff welcomed his release but raised questions about unanswered charges.
British human rights campaigners, including Amnesty International and the Liberty group, expressed outrage at their treatment in Guantanamo Bay, calling for their release.

Amnesty International labeled Camp Delta a "major human-rights scandal" and an "icon of lawlessness," while both organizations and the Guantanamo Human Rights Commission described the Britons' return as long overdue.
Liberty urged the government to either free or charge 12 detainees held in UK prisons without trial, who were ruled unlawful by Law Lords last month but remain incarcerated.
Additionally, Australian Mamdouh Habib, previously charged with terrorist offenses, was also freed from Guantanamo Bay without charge.
Five British detainees released three years ago were questioned by UK police before being released without charge.
